did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.physdesc: Correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, pamphlets, notes, and audio recordings.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Various items documenting the life and work of Charles G. Muller.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Journalist, author, consultant. Cornell University Class of 1918. Charles G. Muller died in 1987. In Cornell University alumni records, his middle name is George; but as an author, he styled himself Charles Geoffrey Muller or Charles G. Muller.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Papers of Charles G. Muller, include diaries (1914-1921) and appointment books (1922-1973) that relate to Muller's activities and attitudes; correspondence, photographs, and scrapbooks concerning his service with an American Red Cross ambulance unit in France (1917) and a trip he took around the world (1919-1920), the latter including Red Cross work in Libau, Latvia; research files for books on the War of 1812, THE PROUDEST DAY: MACDONOUGH ON LAKE CHAMPLAIN (1960) and THE DARKEST DAY: 1814, THE WASHINGTON-BALTIMORE CAMPAIGN (1963); pamphlets, notes, address lists, correspondence, and recorded speeches pertaining to his activities with Alcoholics Anonymous, Alateen, and the National Council on Alcoholism; notes and drafts of NO CORK FOR THE BOTTLE; documentation on many consulting projects, primarily in the field of fund raising; notes, drafts, correspondence, and manuscript for DEMOCRACY'S GIFT DOLLARS; and correspondence, drafts, and notes pertaining to other writing jobs. Also, material relating to Cornell University, and Muller's research material for a March 1984 CORNELL ALUMNI NEWS article "Scotty's Gold Mine," detailing the partnership of Walter Edward Scott (Death Valley Scotty) and Albert Mussey and Bessie Penniman Johnson, and their Death Valley estate, Scotty's Castle.

emph.ref: Series II. Scrapbooks, Memorabilia and Correspondence
Series III. War of 1812 Research Materials

did.abstract: Records events on his trip to England, Scotland, Belgium, Holland, Germany, Switzerland, and Italy.
(no entries Jan. 5-May 16, Oct. 9 Dec. 31) Records activities while in Section 22, Norton Harjes American Red Cross Ambulance Service with the French Army.

(no entries Jan. 1-May 20) Records drive west from Ithaca to Indiana to enlist, back to Syracuse and Ithaca, working at Treman King?s, early writing pursuits, training and service as an aviation pilot with the U.S. Naval Reserve.
Contains accounts of activities in Pensacola, Florida, New York City, Ithaca, and at summer camp and travels in England, France, Spain and St. Nazaire.

Records remainder of stay in Libau for the American Red Cross Commission to Western Russia and travels to Riga, Norway, London, the Antwerp Olympics, Nantes, the Red Sea, the Indian Ocean, China, Vietnam, Japan, Hawaii, California and East to Boston.
(sporadic and usually brief entries) In New York, Ithaca and the mid-west, settled in Michigan where he was reporter and editor for the Grand Rapids Press.

Map of Pisa, postcards, and "Fleeing from the Wrath of Europe", a pamphlet by Mrs. Charles Wentworth (1914); a postcard of a water color, pocket calendar, and a list of authors and their works (1917); photo of troops and a camp and a hotel bill (1920) from the 1918 diary; plan of Toledo, and a postcard of peasants making planks (1919)

did.unittitle: Series II. Scrapbooks, memorabilia and correspondence

did.abstract: Includes photos of people and buildings, pamphlets and programs. A number of items on baseball.

did.unittitle: Photo album of American Red Cross section 22 with the French Army on the Verdun Front (1917) with key
did.abstract: Includes pictures of the trip over, Paris, enroute to Verdun, just behind the lines, time off, and the trip home. Also, key to photo album.

did.unittitle: Journal of Muller?s trip around the world in 1920
did.abstract: Contains visiting cards, a typed journal (Sept. 8 ? Dec. 7, 1920), a story about Peking, "Adrian Acquires Confucius", written in Grand Rapids, "Peking Nights at the Play", vignettes from his trip, and his ship?s itinerary and passenger list.

did.unittitle: "A Trip thru Europe during the summer of 1914"
did.abstract: Collection of letters sent to his parents, George and Jennie (Hodgkinson) Muller from Europe.
Documents, letters, journal entries and the Red Cross Bulletin, miscellaneous issues, June ? Nov. 1921.
Volume contains stories, letters to Charlie and Georgi (Georgia L. Stafroogh) Muller, whom Charlie married in 1921, signed "Kiss". n.d.
Photographs of France, Spain (LaCorida, Toledo), Russia (Libau, Civilian Relief work, Riga), Reine and a few related documents and clippings.

Contains pictures of Sweden and Norway (Bergen), Antwerp, Belgium and the Olympic games, friends, Port Said, the Suez Canal, Djibute, Colombo, Singapore, Saigon, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Puchow, Peking, the Great Wall, Mukden, Korea (Seoul), Japan (Kioto, Mara, Nikko, Kamakura), Honolulu, San Francisco, and Mexico.
U.S. Passport, Red Cross i.d., map of the Front at Verdun, order for transport, two photographs (Muller in 1917), and miscellaneous documents related to Red Cross work.
